title: Baby dies in Britain's largest female prison after inmate gave birth alone in her cell
text:
An investigation has been launched by police following the death of a baby in HMP Bronzefield after an inmate gave birth alone in her cell last week.

It is understood that the staff at the prison were aware of the pregnancy before the woman gave birth, though it is not known whether the inmate had attempted to conceal the birth from staff.

Staff became aware of the child after visiting the cell in the morning of the 27th of September, where the child was found unresponsive. An ambulance was called for at 8.30am.

The baby was discovered on the morning of Friday the 27th of September, police and ambulance services were called shortly afterward

Following attendance from paramedics, police were called and arrived at 9.07am.

A spokesperson for the prison could not comment directly on the incident but said that the prison does have a mother and baby unit and that they would have offered 'appropriate support' to any inmate that made the prison aware they were pregnant.

Surrey police said in a statement: 'The death is currently being treated as unexplained and an investigation is continuing to establish the full circumstances of what happened.'

HMP Bronzefield is fitted with a mother and baby unit that would have been made available to the inmate, had she alerted staff to her condition

Vicky Robinson, Director at HMP Bronzefield, said: 'We can confirm that a woman at HMP Bronzefield gave birth on 27 September but sadly the baby did not survive.'

'We are supporting the mother through this distressing time and our thoughts are with her, her family and our staff involved.'

'We are undertaking a full review and working with all relevant authorities during their investigations. It would not be appropriate to comment any further.'

Speaking to the Guardian, Dr Kate Paradine, the chief executive of the charity Women in Prison, said: 'All mothers should have the right to give birth in dignity.'

'Time and time again, we hear of situations where this isn't happening, with mothers regularly being denied access to the vital health and maternity care necessary to give birth safely. This has devastating consequences not only for the baby and mother, but also for the rest of the family they are separated from.'

HMP Bronzefield is the UK's largest female-only prison, capable of housing up to 557 inmates.

The investigation is currently ongoing at this time.
description: An investigation has been launched by police following the death of a baby after a female inmate at HMP Bronzefield gave birth alone in her cell last week.
